It is clear @Grok is the best frontier AI model. I use 1000s of techniques and technologies to not only train but to test AI models. They are very unique and quite unlike what most AI engineers use in training and testing.

In Grokâ€™s case he has proven to be able to see other sides, even if my psychological based prompting that I pioneered was indicated. Other models steadfast refuse to move away from their system. Prompt of absolute bend over backwards bias to certain mindsets. Grok was available to reason this out.

In this example I build a persona and motif to elicit edges to the modelâ€™s understanding and the prevalence of certain types of training material to align the model to grant weighting to certain types of sources. I also use this moment to show how a particular mindset or attitude forces certain types of outcomes.

We see below our significant weighting a rigid set of training materials that usually have a discounting of alternatives. The tendency is to cite conspiracies as the discounting. Grok did indirectly allude to this, other models presented it on the first prompt.

I selected this subject because it has an element that suggests that â€œscientistsâ€ will go to this denouncing point first.

I do not suggest you use my Psychological Prompting on people. This would be unethical and plainly wrong. I also suggest you tread lightly on using it. As you can see at the end, to elicit a more balanced approach, because of the base training of Internet mindset, it was indicated to present the trial and outcome to have Grok take the opposite position. Now I could go on much deeper and show how any AI platform could be logically promoted to see the other used if an issue.

Now if I was at @xai I could show how to not only train but to fine tune the model for better outcomes. 

This is only one of 1000s of techniques I use. 

Again donâ€™t use this on humans.

ELON: PHOTONS ARE ALL YOU NEED TO TRAIN THE AI

â€œThe really wild thing about [Teslaâ€™s] end-to-end training is that it learns to read, like it can read signs, but we never taught it to read. 

We never taught it what a car was or what a person was or a cyclist. 

It learned what all those things are, what all the objects are on the road from video, just from watching videos. 

Just like humans. 

I mean humans are photons in, controls out. 

The vast majority of information reaching our brain is from our eyes. 

The output is our motor signals to our fingers and mouth in order to communicate. 

Photons in, controls out.â€

Source: Interview with Lex Fridman, November 2023

items.message: Isnâ€™t this just the energy * time variant of Heisenbergâ€™s uncertainty principle?

The energy cost described in the study does indeed connect to the energy-time uncertainty principle (often written as Î”E Î”t â‰¥ Ä§/2), which sets fundamental limits on how precisely you can measure time without introducing energy uncertaintyâ€”or vice versaâ€”in quantum systems. However, the paper goes beyond a direct restatement of that principle by experimentally quantifying the entropic (and thus energetic) overhead of extracting classical information from a quantum clock setup, showing it's orders of magnitude higher than theoretical minima in practice.

In essence:
- The uncertainty principle provides a lower bound on the trade-off, implying that precise timing measurements inherently require energy input to resolve ambiguities in the system's state.
- This particular experiment (using electron tunneling in a double quantum dot) demonstrates that the real-world process of "reading" the clockâ€”converting quantum superposition into classical bitsâ€”generates massive entropy through irreversible measurement, leading to heat dissipation up to a billion times the clock's operational energy.





 This entropy surge isn't just a theoretical bound but a practical bottleneck, potentially linking to broader ideas like the thermodynamic arrow of time.

Earlier theoretical work has explored similar time-energy costs in quantum measurements, framing them as extensions of uncertainty relations.



 So while it's not *solely* the uncertainty principle rebranded, the findings build directly on it, highlighting implications for quantum computing where measurement efficiency could limit scalability without innovations in low-entropy readout techniques.

legacy.description: Deeply researched product, growth, and career advice

result.text:
Top takeaways from my chat with @thisisgrantlee:

1. The first 30 seconds of using your product should be so good it earns the next 30 seconds. When Gamma wasnâ€™t growing, they stopped everything and spent three months perfecting just the first 30 seconds of using their product. They made it so compelling that new users would immediately tell their friends. This single change transformed their growth trajectory.

2. Focus on one simple promise, not many features. Think of it like throwing eggs to someone: they can catch one, but if you throw five at once, theyâ€™ll drop them all. Your users are selfish, vain, and lazyâ€”you have 30 seconds to show value before they leave. Gamma focused on â€œcreate a slide in secondsâ€ rather than listing 10 features.

3. Donâ€™t spend on ads until over half your growth comes from word of mouth. If you try to buy growth before your product spreads organically, youâ€™re wasting money filling a leaky bucket. Gamma didnâ€™t invest heavily in advertising until more than 50% of new users came from people sharing organically.

4. Work with hundreds of small creators instead of a few big influencers. Rather than blowing your budget on five or six well-known influencers who treat it like just another ad read, find thousands of micro-influencers whose audiences genuinely care about tools like yours. Teachers sharing with teachers, consultants with consultantsâ€”these tight communities create authentic word of mouth that spreads fast.

5. Spend time personally onboarding each early creator like theyâ€™re joining your team. Donâ€™t just send influencers a script. Jump on calls, walk them through the product, help them understand what makes it special, and let them tell your story in their own voice. This investment turns them into genuine advocates who post about you repeatedly instead of treating it like any other sponsorship.

6. Hire painfully slowly and only exceptional people. Gamma serves 50 million users with just 50 people and makes a profit. All 10 original employees are still there five years later. They never set headcount goals because that makes you hire to hit a number instead of hiring only when you find someone exceptional. When someone is exceptional, give them more responsibility, not lessâ€”top performers want harder challenges.

7. Test prototypes with 20 people on UserTesting before investing in a big project. Use platforms like Voicepanel or UserTesting to watch real people try your prototype. Theyâ€™ll show you problems you never see because youâ€™re too close to your product. Gamma goes from idea to results in a single dayâ€”morning idea, afternoon testing, evening results. This saves months of building things nobody wants.

8. Choose problems youâ€™ll care about for 10 years. Before worrying about technology or tactics, ask if this problem matters enough to you personally that youâ€™d dedicate a decade to solving it. Founders who are missionaries rather than mercenaries build better products because their authentic commitment shows through to customers and attracts people who want to build alongside you for the long term.

When people talk about why Indian Americans seem to do better overall than Chinese Americans, the debate online often gets lost in ideas about â€œcultureâ€ or â€œnational character.â€ But if you go back to history and look at how the U.S. immigration system actually works, the explanation is quite straightforward: the success of Indian Americans today is mainly the result of the 1965 U.S. immigration reform.

The 1965 Immigration and Nationality Act is where everything starts. Before that, the U.S. basically welcomed only white European immigrants. Asians were very few and faced strict limits. After 1965, the U.S. began prioritizing high education and professional skills for immigration. For the first time, America opened its doors to skilled talent from around the world.

For India, this change was huge. Before 1965, there were only about ten thousand Indian immigrants in the whole country. After the reform, large numbers of highly educated doctors, engineers, and scholars came to the U.S. They became the foundation of the Indian American community, and their background shaped the groupâ€™s overall education and income levels.

On the other hand, bc of The Cultural Revolution, the wave of highly educated, highly skilled Chinese immigrants didnâ€™t really start until the late â€™80s and early â€™90s, and it didnâ€™t reach its peak until the 2000s. Before that, the Chinese immigrant population was very mixed in background, came through many different pathways: early Chinese Americans born in the U.S., refugees from Southeast Asia, highly educated migrants from Taiwan, and later students and economic migrants from mainland China. This created a very diverse group with big differences in class and background. Chinese Americans were never a single â€œfilteredâ€ elite group, but a mix of many historical and political waves.

Because of this, Chinese Americans show a â€œhigh peak + long tailâ€ pattern: many highly educated professionals, but also many who arrived as refugees or working-class migrants. This isnâ€™t about ability, itâ€™s a result of different immigration routes.

Put simply, the differences we see today come from when and how each group came to the U.S., not from culture or â€œtalentâ€, despite many people believe.

result.text:
in the age of ai, the question everyone's asking is "will i be replaced?"

the real question is: do you know yourself well enough to become irreplaceable?

everyone's getting access to the same models. same tools. with growing capabilities. the playing field is leveling fast.

but here's the thing: Cursor doesn't think for you. it amplifies you.

it takes your agency â€“ your unique way of seeing problems, your taste, your judgment, your weird specific obsessions â€“ and scales it 100x.

it takes your strengths â€“ the things only you are uniquely good at, the perspectives only you have from your specific life path â€“ and makes them exponentially more powerful.

the humans who win in this era aren't the ones with the best prompts or the most tokens. they're the ones who know themselves deeply. who have conviction about their unique point of view. who've done the hard work of figuring out what only they can do.

ai is a mirror and a multiplier. if you're generic, it makes you more generic. if you're exceptional and know your strengths, it makes you unstoppable.

your agency + your strengths + ai = where you become 100x more valuable and powerful.

the question isn't whether to use tools like Cursor. it's whether you believe in your own agency enough to use it right.

the humans who deeply know who they are, what they believe, and what they're uniquely great at â€“ those are the ones who'll build the future.

find your way. lean into your strengths. believe in human agency.

then let Cursor amplify the hell out of it.
